programs.description: Genes encoding ion transporters and channels essential for astrocyte buffering capacity and cellular volume regulation, including aquaporins, sodium-potassium ATPases, and potassium channels critical for maintaining extracellular ion concentrations and preventing excitotoxicity in the brain.

atomic_biological_processes.name: Potassium buffering and extracellular ion homeostasis

citations.notes: Gene network analysis demonstrates importance of ion transport genes in maintaining cellular homeostasis; study utilized expression data relevant to understanding astrocyte function
Gene co-expression analysis identifies calcium regulatory networks; relevant to understanding astrocyte calcium dynamics
Transcriptomic analysis identifies membrane transport proteins as key cellular components
Gene expression analysis demonstrates role of aquaporins in cellular water transport and volume regulation

predicted_cellular_impact: Enhanced potassium buffering capacity to counteract excitotoxicity and neuronal hyperexcitability
Maintained cellular volume through osmotic regulation
Sustained calcium signaling for astrocyte-neuron communication
Preserved extracellular ion homeostasis in tumor microenvironment
Dysregulated ion handling potentially contributing to astrocytoma growth
programs.evidence_summary: This program clusters genes encoding ion transporters and channels fundamental to astrocyte physiology. Multiple aquaporins (AQP4, AQP1), sodium-potassium ATPase (ATP1A2), potassium channels (KCNN3, KCNQ5), and bicarbonate transporters (SLC4A4, SLC1A3) form a coordinated system for maintaining ionic gradients and cellular volume. In astrocytoma, dysregulation of these transporters could enhance tumor cell survival and migration while impairing normal supportive astrocyte functions.

citations.notes: Comprehensive gene co-expression network analysis provides framework for understanding interconnected ion transport functions in brain tissue

programs.description: Genes encoding structural proteins, adhesion molecules, and cytoskeletal regulators that control cell morphology, migration, and intercellular contacts. Includes formins, integrins, cadherins, and associated regulatory proteins critical for astrocyte process extension and tissue organization.

citations.notes: Gene network analysis identifies clusters of cytoskeletal regulators coordinating cellular architecture
Network analysis reveals cadherin and adhesion-related gene clusters important for tissue organization
Transcriptomic profiling identifies actin regulators as central to cytoskeletal networks
Gene co-expression patterns highlight interconnected adhesion and junction proteins
Network analysis reveals genes involved in cell-matrix interactions and integrin signaling

predicted_cellular_impact: Enhanced cell migration and invasive capacity in tumor context
Altered astrocyte morphology with retracted processes favoring tumoral phenotype
Disrupted gap junction communication between astrocytes and neurons
Modified cell-matrix interactions affecting tumor microenvironment interaction
Loss of normal astrocyte tiling and supportive network organization
programs.evidence_summary: This program aggregates genes regulating actin dynamics, cell adhesion, and structural organization. Formins (FMN2, DAAM2), Rho-family GTPase regulators (ARHGAP26, ARHGEF4), and adhesion molecules (PCDH9, CDH20, TJP2) enable astrocytes to form branched morphologies and maintain tissue architecture. In astrocytoma, dysregulation of these factors—particularly increased formin activity or loss of adhesion—promotes tumor cell migration and disrupts the organized astrocytic scaffold that normally supports neural circuits.

citations.notes: Integrative gene network analysis demonstrates coordinated expression of cytoskeletal and adhesion genes

programs.description: Genes encoding neurotrophic factors, their receptors, and downstream signaling mediators that regulate survival, differentiation, and synaptic plasticity. Includes NTRK2, LIFR, ERBB4, and related signaling components critical for astrocyte-neuron crosstalk and neuroprotection.

citations.notes: Gene network analysis identifies receptor tyrosine kinase signaling clusters relevant to cell fate determination
Transcriptomic analysis reveals coordinated expression of MAPK pathway components
Gene expression profiling identifies receptor proteins central to signal transduction

predicted_cellular_impact: Enhanced pro-survival signaling pathways driving astrocytoma progression
Dysregulated neurotrophic factor responses favoring tumor over supportive phenotype
Altered neuronal-astrocytic coupling through dysregulated ERBB and NTRK signaling
Enhanced resistance to apoptosis through activated LIFR and related pathways
Impaired neuroprotective astrocyte functions
programs.evidence_summary: This program clusters genes involved in growth factor signaling critical for astrocyte survival and neuroprotection. NTRK2 (TrkB) and ERBB4 are receptor tyrosine kinases responding to brain-derived neurotrophic factor and neuregulins respectively. LIFR mediates leukemia inhibitory factor signaling supporting astrocyte survival. Downstream effectors include MAP kinases (MAP3K5, MAPK4) and stress-responsive proteins (DAPK1). In astrocytoma, alterations in this pathway could shift balance from neuroprotective to tumorigenic phenotypes.

citations.notes: Gene co-expression networks reveal interconnected growth factor signaling clusters

programs.description: Genes involved in lipid synthesis, modification, and trafficking essential for myelin support and astrocyte-mediated lipid delivery to neurons. Includes fatty acid desaturases, oxysterol-binding proteins, and lipid transport proteins.

citations.notes: Methylation and expression analysis identifies lipid metabolism genes in differential expression signatures
Gene networks implicate oxysterol-binding proteins in lipid homeostasis
Transcriptomic analysis identifies proteins involved in intracellular lipid trafficking

predicted_cellular_impact: Enhanced lipid synthesis supporting tumor cell membrane expansion
Dysregulated cholesterol and fatty acid metabolism affecting myelination support
Altered astrocyte-neuron lipid transfer mechanisms
Modified membrane composition affecting cell signaling and drug sensitivity
Impaired lipid-dependent neuroprotective functions
programs.evidence_summary: This program encompasses genes controlling lipid synthesis, modification, and intracellular trafficking. FADS2 catalyzes fatty acid desaturation essential for polyunsaturated fatty acid production. Oxysterol-binding proteins (OSBPL11, OSBPL3) facilitate sterol and lipid binding and transport. SORL1 mediates apolipoprotein E (APOE) recycling, critical for astrocyte-mediated lipid delivery to neurons. In astrocytoma, dysregulation could favor anabolic lipid synthesis for membrane biogenesis and energy storage while impairing supportive lipid delivery to neurons.

citations.notes: Differential gene expression analysis identifies metabolic gene signatures
Gene co-expression networks reveal lipid metabolism clusters

programs.description: Genes encoding transcription factors, chromatin remodelers, and regulatory proteins controlling astrocyte differentiation, identity, and responses to developmental or pathological cues. Includes ID proteins, YAP1, and associated chromatin regulators.

citations.notes: Multimodal single-cell analysis identifies transcription factor networks driving cell fate decisions and differentiation
Gene network analysis reveals Hippo pathway components in cellular state determination
Single-cell analysis identifies key transcription factors and their regulatory networks

predicted_cellular_impact: Altered astrocyte differentiation and identity maintenance in tumor context
Dysregulated transcriptional networks promoting glioma-initiating cell programs
Enhanced stemness or de-differentiation phenotypes
Loss of mature astrocyte gene expression programs
Aberrant mechanotransduction through YAP1 dysregulation
programs.evidence_summary: This program gathers transcription factors and regulators of astrocyte fate. ID proteins (ID3, ID4) inhibit differentiation-promoting bHLH factors, maintaining progenitor-like states when overexpressed. RFX4 regulates CFTR expression and may modulate astrocyte identity. YAP1, a Hippo pathway effector, acts as a mechanotransducer coupling physical cues to gene expression. In astrocytoma, dysregulation of these factors could drive de-differentiation toward glioma stem cell phenotypes, away from mature supportive astrocyte functions.

citations.notes: Multimodal single-cell analysis reveals transcription factor networks matching known and emerging TF interactions
Gene co-expression networks implicate transcriptional regulators in cell fate programs

clustering_basis: Functional annotation from literature: ion transport, cytoskeletal regulation, signaling pathways, metabolism, transcriptional control
Gene ontology enrichment patterns: cellular component and biological process categories
Known pathway participation: Hippo signaling, MAPK cascades, synaptic plasticity networks
Astrocyte-specific roles: potassium buffering, metabolic support, neuroprotection
Astrocytoma context: consideration of normal functions inverted toward tumorigenesis
method.notes: This analysis identifies five major gene programs from the provided list relevant to astrocytoma biology. While the provided search results do not contain direct characterization of all genes in this list within the astrocytoma context, clustering rationale is grounded in established astrocyte biology and how such genes would be perturbed in malignant transformation. Ion transport represents the core astrocyte identity. Cytoskeletal and adhesion genes enable phenotypic shifts toward migratory phenotypes. Neurotrophic signaling controls survival. Lipid metabolism supports membranous expansion. Transcriptional regulators enable fate changes. Each program represents a coordinated functional unit likely dysregulated in astrocytoma CNMF cluster programs.
